cards.html: This is our regular Weekend Reading List, a subscriber-only feature that reviews some major must-reads of the week. If you only read one email from us all week, this one should be it, because it reviews everything we’ve done all week.

This newsletter relies on our current subscribers encouraging others to also become subscribers. If you are a monthly subscriber who wants to upgrade to an annual subscription, click here and click “change” in the “Plan” setting. Thanks for your support!

Bernie Sanders: The U.S. Must Stop Being an Apologist for the Netanyahu Government

“We have seen Benjamin Netanyahu’s government work to marginalize and demonize Palestinian citizens of Israel, pursue settlement policies designed to foreclose the possibility of a two-state solution and pass laws that entrench systemic inequality between Jewish and Palestinian citizens of Israel. None of this excuses the attacks by Hamas, which were an attempt to exploit the unrest in Jerusalem, or the failures of the corrupt and ineffective Palestinian Authority, which recently postponed long-overdue elections. But the fact of the matter is that Israel remains the one sovereign authority in the land of Israel and Palestine, and rather than preparing for peace and justice, it has been entrenching its unequal and undemocratic control.”
Teshuvah: A Jewish Case for Palestinian Refugee Return

In Jewish discourse, this refusal to forget the past — or accept its verdict — evokes deep pride. The late philosopher Isaiah Berlin once boasted that Jews ‘have longer memories’ than other peoples. And in the late 19th century, Zionists harnessed this long collective memory to create a movement for return to a territory most Jews had never seen. ‘After being forcibly exiled from their land, the people kept faith with it throughout their Dispersion,’ proclaims Israel’s Declaration of Independence. The State of Israel constitutes ‘the realization’ of this ‘age-old dream.’ Why is dreaming of return laudable for Jews but pathological for Palestinians?”
Is Beef the New Coal? Climate-Friendly Eating Is on the Rise

“Beef could be the new coal, shunned by elite tastemakers over rising temperatures and squeezed by increasingly cheap alternatives… Americans do claim to want a shift. Seventy percent say it would be healthier if the country ate less meat and 58% would like to eat more fruits, vegetables, nuts and whole grains, according to a 2020 survey by the food market research firm Datassential. Worries about climate pile on top of long-standing health concerns about red meat.”
Big Oil Is Trying to Make Climate Change Your Problem to Solve

“The framing of climate change, in particular, as something that wouldn’t be an issue if ‘we’ had all just made better consumer choices has been persistent and effective. Every Earth Day, we’re bombarded with tips about how to minimize our personal carbon footprints; meanwhile, it’s 2021 and the GOP is still suggesting tree-planting as climate policy… A new paper from Harvard science historians Naomi Oreskes and Geoffrey Supran shows that this sort of framing is no accident, it was by design.”
Why Is Covid Killing So Many Young Children in Brazil?
“Covid-19 is ravaging Brazil, and, in a disturbing new wrinkle that experts are working to understand, it appears to be killing babies and small children at an unusually high rate.”

The showdown in New York — where a private equity firm turned a moth-balled coal power plant into one fired by natural gas that provides electricity to mine bitcoin onsite — is part of an increasingly fraught debate over the social benefits and environmental costs of the world's most popular cryptocurrency.”
Former Navy Pilot Says Flight Crews Observed UFOs “Every Day For At Least A Couple Years

“Graves is one of several current and former military members who have spoken publicly about what the Pentagon now calls unidentified aerial phenomena or UAP. These documented sightings of UAP, recorded on gun camera video and photos taken by U.S. service members, have been analyzed by the Defense Department for years. But the government only grudgingly acknowledged the internal efforts after unclassified videos of UAP were leaked to the New York Times in 2017. Now, the Senate Intelligence Committee has ordered the Director of National Intelligence and the Secretary of Defense to compile a report on unidentified aerial phenomena to be delivered next month.”

This week, I felt simultaneously proud of all the work we are doing here at
, and I felt overwhelmed by the sheer amount of news happening 24-7, frustrated that we are not yet at the scale to deeply cover it all.
In just five days last week, our small team's reporting exposed
Denny's admission about a $15 minimum wage
. These are stories about corruption and economic violence that corporate media ignores — and we were able to nail them, thanks to support from our subscribers.

At the same time, though, the news was dominated by Israel's violent assault in Gaza — a hugely important, complex topic. Some have asked us why we didn't immediately drop everything to cover that story — which is an inquiry we get about every hugely important topic whenever news breaks anywhere in the world.
The queries are absolutely fair. I share the abiding desire to deeply cover every single topic in the world, and part of what we do with features like

is spotlight other people's good reporting and commentary on a wide variety of topics (see today's links about the Israeli violence). But I want you to know I share your frustration that while our small team is producing terrific journalism, we are not yet at a size and scale to produce original reporting on literally every topic that deserves coverage.
I also want you to know that reality doesn't mean we don't
about those topics (As one example: I am personally outraged by the war crimes Israel has been committing; I have long believed Benjamin Netanyahu is a monster and
; and the fact that the violence is being committed in the name of my own religion deeply depresses and enrages me).

Put another way: Our present coverage limitations do not reflect a values decision. They reflect our still-small size, and the reason we are working so hard to grow our subscriber base, which will allow us to hire more reporters and do more journalism.

Every single day, our team tries to make good decisions about how to best deploy our still-limited reporting resources. But as a small, reader-supported news outlet, our question is not just, what is the big news of the day? Our questions are also: What is

being covered that deserves coverage? What coverage gaps can we fill that have the best chance to make the most impact? How can we most effectively use our small team's specific expertise to not just repeat what's already being said, but to instead actually add something new and substantive to the conversation?
As one of our subscribers, you deserve to know about our decision-making process — and an integral part of that process is your feedback. You should always email us at
or post a comment to let us know about what kind of coverage you want. That input is absolutely essential.

You don't have to agree with everything we do — but I hope you will at least appreciate that we are earnestly trying to make the best editorial decisions possible, always asking how we can make the most impact.
Thanks as always for your ongoing support. We could not do this work without you. Onward.
